In late 1964, the starting five of Franks, Roger Haley, Jack Burkhart, Terry Collins and C.W. Crandall knew they had a strong unit, but never would have imagined a 44-2 season with a state championship — and winning every state tournament game by double digits.

Other members of the 1964-65 team included Benny Magness, Curtis Lackey, Matt Smith, Michael McCracken, Richard Queen, Bernie Miller, Phillip Anglin, Roger Smith, Jimmy Kemp, Mike Parks and Duane Grigg.

shared_text:
Ken Buck
March 18 at 8:47 AM ·

We gave educators almost no notice. We asked them to completely redesign what school looks like and in about 24 hours local administrators and teachers "Apollo 13'ed" the problem and fixed it. Kids learning, children being fed, needs being met in the midst of a global crisis.
No state agency did this, no so-called national experts on curriculum. The local educators fixed it in hours. HOURS.
In fact, existing state and federal policies actually created multiple roadblocks. Local schools figured out how to do it around those too. No complaining and no handwringing - just solutions and amazingly clever plans.
Remember that the next time someone tries to convince you that schools are better run by mandates from non-educators. Remember that the next time someone tells you that teachers have it easy or try to persuade you that educators are not among the smartest, most ingenious people in society. And please never say to me again, "Those who can't do anything else just go into teaching."
Get out of the way of a teacher and watch with amazement at what really happens.

Kate Cheek and Tylar Coots have recently been working with fourth grade classes to teach students about the American Enterprise System. Their goals are to teach the classes about their guaranteed rights and freedoms as Americans: the ability to choose and decide your own job, land, and life. They did this by having the students participate in a simulation activity. Students had to make life choices such as: choosing between properties, weighing the risk and reward of different jobs, etc. After this simulation and a small presentation, the students scored 20-30% higher on a small American Enterprise quiz.

Great work, Kate and Tylar!

❤️💙For the Love of Reading Book Drive💙❤️

The CHS Interact Club will be hosting our 2nd annual Book Drive starting Wednesday, January 15th. Last year we were able to donate over 300 books to our Elementary students and classrooms!!

If you would like to donate children's books in new or excellent condition (appropriate for ages PK-6th grade) we will be accepting donations through January 30th. Books can be brought to the High School or Elementary Offices. The Interact students will be working the car rider line in the elementary on Friday, January 17 and we would be happy to accept your books then as well.

Community members wanting to participate can drop books off at the First Security Bank Branch locations in Gassville and across from the Harps in Mtn Home.

shared_text:
Mountain Home Rotary is with Wes Wood.
December 17, 2019 at 11:20 AM ·

On December 12, our special guests were some of the 13 area students that our club had sent to "Rotary Youth Leadership Awards" (RYLA) this past fall. These juniors from Cotter High and Mountain Home High spent a 4-day weekend at camp in Oklahoma with hundreds more from our 4-state district. They were accompanied by RYLA chair Rick Steiner with assistance from Renae Schocke who went as chaperones. The young people learned self-discipline, formed bonds, built self-confidence, and trusted each other for support and encouragement! As each student spoke, they unanimously thanked the club for their scholarship to attend RYLA and they told us it "was the best experience I've ever had" and "I'm a better person for it".
Mark Hopper with the Past Presidents Council also presented the "Featured Rotarian of the Month" to Perry McDonald (November) and to RYLA Coordinator Rick Steiner (December). They join Trevor Himschoot who was selected for October. Thanks to all the Rotarians who rang Salvation Army bells on Friday at Harp's. "Service Above Self!" Rick Steiner, Renae Schocke

Attention Warriors young and old, past and present.... Homecoming week starts Monday!

Monday- Thursday dress up days are for 4th-12th grades only.
Friday is Spirit day for ALL students and staff.
The homecoming ceremony starts at 5:30pm on Friday in the High School Gym.
The homecoming game starts immediately after the ceremony with Senior boys and Senior girls teams taking on Green Forest.
There will be a homecoming dance beginning at 8pm Friday night for grades 7-12.

We thank all those who have given so much for our freedom. 🇱🇷

Stay warm!
